answers.answer: Hi!I am sorry to hear about your medical problems.  Tongue numbness can be the first sign of Bell’s palsy, peripheral neuropathy due to diabetes or hypothyroidsm or lupus, MS, vitamin B 12 deficiency, or due to a mini stroke. Please get this investigated immediately.Take care!The medical advice given should not be considered a substitute for medical care provided by a doctor who can examine you. The advice may not be completely correct for you as the doctor cannot examine you and does not know your complete medical history. Hence this reply to your post should only be considered as a guiding line and you must consult your doctor at the earliest for your medical problem.

question: I am currently experiencing numbness with my tongue that cause extreme fatigue and makes it difficult to talk, I also have trouble remembering simple tasks and focusing. I also have a lump under my chin that I was told was just fat but I know that it's not because some days it appears bigger and I will wake up with my jaw area feeling swollen and will last throughout the day. And I wake up with my muscles aching (it feels like the pain you have when you have the flu but worse) and will also last throughout the day. And if I sit or stand for too long my legs will cramp up and it is painful to walk. Recently I'm noticing numbness in my fingertips. I have been to many doctors and no one has figured it out. Wondering if anybody may be familiar with these symptoms and may be able to direct me for help.
title: Tongue numbness and fatigue
